header.article_title: Gary Johnson’s Media Meltdown Leads to All Time High Favorability of 21%
header.author: Ashwin Misra
header.tags: Politics, Politicians, Election, Gary Johnson, Hillary Clinton, Donald Trump

body.p: BOULDER, COGary Johnson’s campaign has now been noticed by the general public after the traumatic, hard-to-watch video of him surfaced the Internet. The video showed a hot-tempered Johnson defending the inevitable “why are you even in the campaign?” question. The Libertarian Party candidate assures a win after re-watching his public media meltdown about the two main candidates. “Just look at the polls, Anderson. I’m at a whole 4.6% right now! I’d say I got this one in the bag. Oh boy is it looking good for me, huh? We’re practically on double digits! Just wait until the fourth debate and my numbers will shoot way up.” said a red-faced Johnson, who added that his favorability numbers (of just 21%) are higher than “any president in the history of America”. After having a private conversation with Johnson’s VP pick- William Weld- we learned a great deal of useful information. “Really I don’t know what Gary and I are still doing here. He’s a lost cause, in all seriousness.” Weld also added that Gary Johnson will be “the most irrelevant presidential candidate in modern US history”. We visited Weld at the Libertarian Party office a week later only to find him emptying the office. I think we all know what this means.

report.p: This satirical article is about the outburst Gary Johnson had when speaking with and interviewer. It discusses the effects of said outburst in terms of how Candidate Johnson sees it in contrast with how his VP Candidate sees it. The lack of faith coming from William Weld in his own campaign I think is the best part of the satirical article, as the clear contrast between the standpoints of Johnson and Weld embodies the feel of a satirical article. One critique I have is that nearly all of the text is quoted which means that very little of the body is written from the "writer of the article" which I guess would be you, even though the quotes were written by you as well. The image you are using is funny and contextual, but it's clear that it is a screengrab and seems like something else could fit better in the framework of an article. You focus mostly on the responses to the outburst that took place during the interview and not the outburst itself. I found this picture https://c.o0bg.com/rf/image_960w/Boston/2011-2020/2016/06/01/BostonGlobe.com/Politics/Images/johnson-weld.jpg that demonstrates a more subtle relation to your article with the differences in facial expressions of Johnson and Weld. The title of your article also sounds a little bit too real, like something I might read on an informative news site. Remember that in satirical articles, the title is often most of, or the whole joke. Maybe you could reword it so that the joke is a little more blunt. Something like: Johnson: "Yes we can." Weld: "No we can't." You shouldn't take my advice verbatim obviously, but I think that the contrast used for humor in the article can be squeezed a little more in the title. With some revisions, I think this is a really good idea for a satirical article and could easily fit in within the context of a site like the onion.
